mcqs.question: Which element is inline by default?
mcqs.explanation: `<span>` is an inline element.

mcqs.question: What happens when you place an inline element inside a block-level element?
options: It is not allowed in HTML
It is valid and renders normally
It will convert the block element to inline
mcqs.explanation: It is valid to nest inline elements inside block-level elements.

mcqs.question: Which of these is NOT a block-level element?
mcqs.explanation: `<em>` is an inline element.

mcqs.question: Which block-level element is used to group HTML elements together?
mcqs.explanation: `<div>` is commonly used as a generic container for grouping elements.

mcqs.question: Which tag is used for grouping inline elements?
mcqs.explanation: `<span>` is used to group inline elements.

mcqs.question: How is the display property related to block and inline elements?
options: It can change an element from block to inline and vice versa
mcqs.explanation: You can use CSS `display` to change whether an element is block or inline.

mcqs.question: If a block-level element is placed inside an inline element, what usually happens?
options: It may cause unexpected layout or validation errors
It is recommended by HTML standards
The inline element will be ignored
mcqs.explanation: This is invalid in HTML and may cause layout issues.

mcqs.question: Which element is always rendered on a new line?
mcqs.explanation: `<div>` is a block-level element and always starts on a new line.

mcqs.question: Which of the following is TRUE about inline elements?
options: They always start on a new line
They take up as much width as possible
They take up only as much width as necessary
mcqs.explanation: Inline elements only take up as much width as their content requires.

mcqs.question: Which of the following is a valid block-level element?
mcqs.explanation: `<nav>` is a block-level element.

mcqs.question: Which of the following is an inline element?
mcqs.explanation: `<code>` is an inline element.

mcqs.question: Which is a block-level element that represents a section of content?
mcqs.explanation: `<aside>` is a block-level element used for side content.

mcqs.question: What is the default display value for `<div>`?
mcqs.explanation: `<div>` is rendered as a block element by default.

mcqs.question: Which inline element is used for emphasized text?
mcqs.explanation: `<em>` is used for emphasized inline text.

mcqs.question: How do block-level elements generally behave?
options: They only take as much width as their content
They stack vertically and take full available width
mcqs.explanation: Block-level elements stack vertically and take up the full width.

mcqs.question: Which of the following is NOT an inline element?
mcqs.explanation: `<section>` is a block-level element.

mcqs.question: Can you change an element from block to inline using CSS?
options: No, only JavaScript can do this
mcqs.explanation: The CSS `display` property can change an element's display type.

mcqs.question: Which element is best for marking up a short phrase within a paragraph?
mcqs.explanation: `<span>` is ideal for marking short phrases inline within text.

mcqs.question: Which of the following statements about block and inline elements is TRUE?
options: Block elements can contain inline elements
Inline elements can contain block elements
Inline elements always start on a new line
mcqs.explanation: Block-level elements can contain inline elements, but not vice versa.
